title: 110_hr673
content: The "Cocopah Lands Act" is the short title of this legislation. It includes findings related to the act. The Cocopah Tribe's reservation in Yuma County, Arizona, was created in 1917 by President Woodrow Wilson. The Tribe's land holdings consist of approximately 6,226.3 acres of trust land across 3 noncontiguous reservations. Additional lands were purchased to support housing, water, and economic development for tribal members. However, the current trust land base is insufficient to meet these needs. The Tribe acquired 7 parcels of land contiguous to its reservation in 1986, 1993, 1997, and 2005, which are classified as "Tribal fee lands" under Federal law. The Cocopah Tribe's reservation in Yuma County, Arizona was established in 1917. They have acquired parcels of land classified as "Tribal fee lands" under Federal law. The acquired parcels cannot be used for gaming purposes. The best solution for the Tribe's land and economic needs is for the Secretary to take these lands into trust for the Tribe. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Tribe" refers to the Cocopah Tribe of Arizona, and "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 4. LANDS TO BE TAKEN INTO TRUST. If the Tribe transfers land to the Secretary, it will be taken into trust if there are no environmental issues or legal claims. The described land includes specific parcels in Yuma County, Arizona. Specific parcels in Yuma County, Arizona include various lots and portions of land purchased in different years by different individuals. Specific parcels in Yuma County, Arizona include various lots and portions of land purchased in different years by different individuals. The easterly 15 feet of the north 220 feet of the NW\1/4\ of the NE\1/4\ of Sec. 31, T. 16 S., R. 22 E., of the San Bernardino Base and Meridian, Yuma County, Arizona, lying north of the levee and Salinity Canal for irrigation purposes. Parcel 6 includes Lots 21, 24, and 25 in Sec. 29, and Lots 16 and 17 and the N\1/2\ of the SW\1/4\ of the SE\1/4\ of Sec. 30. Parcel 7 consists of a portion of the W\1/2\ of the SE\1/4\ of Sec. 30, T. 9 S., R. 23 W., of the Gila and Salt River Base and Meridian, Yuma County, Arizona. Land taken into trust in Yuma County, Arizona will become part of the Tribe's reservation. The Tribe's service area for federal services will be Yuma County. Gaming on the land taken into trust is prohibited under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act. The House of Representatives passed the bill on July 30, 2007.
